statement:
If a finite group is the product of two nilpotent subgroups, then it is
solvable.

That is, if $H$ and $K$ are nilpotent subgroups of a finite group $G$,
and $G=HK$, then $G$ is solvable.

This result can be considered as a generalization of , because if a
group $G$ is of order $p^m q^n$, where $p$ and $q$ are distinct primes,
then $G$ is the product of a and Sylow $q$-subgroup, both of which are
nilpotent.
